→ Will Swift Developers Need Objective-C?

Jun 12, 2014 • ∞
1 minute read

Marco Arment on whether future Swift developers will need to have a solid grasp of Objective-C:

I agree with Aaron Hillegass, but only short-term. If you want to develop for iOS in the next year or two, you should probably know Objective-C. But in a few years, I don’t think it’ll matter if you only learn Swift.

Later on:

The time will come when knowing Objective-C will be like knowing C, C++, or assembly — it’ll be a plumbing layer beneath your application code that almost all working developers will never need to know or interact with. And I bet that time is less than five years away — possibly just two or three.

I’m not sold on this. The truth is that, only a few weeks removed from WWDC, we don’t know all that much about Apple’s new programming language. Craig Federighi boasted of huge performance gains, but we’ve yet to see those in practice (or whether the compiler optimizations needed for such speed increases will be safe in real world applications).

Right now, the only reason Swift could supplant Objective-C’s necessity is Apple’s backing power.1 That’s it. Apple wants the world to begin developing Swift-based apps; therefore, it will inevitably happen, regardless of whether the paradigm shift is correct. In time, Swift may emerge as a finely tuned machine, but let’s be clear: that day isn’t today (and it may not come for some time). Therefore, Objective-C isn’t going anywhere anytime soon.

I hope I’m wrong. There’s a lot to dislike about the bulkiness of Objective-C (especially in Apple’s context); I want Swift to be a better option (in fact, such a “better option” that Objective-C recedes into the background). Only time will tell if it has that ability.

  1. There’s no real reason for this, but I’m skeptical of a closed-source, closed-environment programming language. Yes, Objective-C was Apple’s pet for the past decade, but they didn’t invent the language. I truly have to wonder: what’s the staying power of a brand-new language created for a closed purpose in an environment that isn’t friendly to outsiders?  ↩
